title: Anti-Politics: Characterising and Accounting for Political Disaffection
abstractText:
Our aim in this research project is to develop a more nuanced understanding of the nature and potential sources of political disaffection by conducting a series of focus groups with citizens.

The research draws on a base of annual survey-based audits undertaken into political engagement conducted for the Hansard Society since 2004 and a key objective of the research is to build on existing data sets to expand our knowledge of an important topic: why so many citizens are disillusioned with politics.

The research provides a testing ground for existing explanations of political and it allows for the emergence of unexplored and unidentified factors in the explanation of political disaffection by providing an open analysis of the carefully recorded proceedings of the focus groups. It will make an immediate impact on the policy and practitioner debate about anti-politics and the open policy arena for reform measures created by the Coalition government in the UK because it will tied to the prominent and authoritative surveys run by the Hansard Society since 2004 but will provide a more fleshed out understanding of factors behind anti-politics and therefore the appropriateness of various solutions.
impactText: Findings have informed debate about political disenchantment as reflected in media coverage and interst of practitioners Government, Democracy and Justice Policy & public services
